title: 105_s1112
content: The "United States Buffalo Nickel Act of 1997" mandates the minting of 5-cent coins with specific specifications for a 3-year period. The coins will weigh 5 grams, have a diameter of 0.835 inch, and contain an alloy of 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will only obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stockpiling Act. The design of the coins will be specified under this Act. The design requirements for the coins minted under this Act are based on the original 5-cent coin designed by James Earle Fraser. Each coin will feature a profile of a Native American on the obverse side and a buffalo on the reverse side, along with inscriptions of value, year, and patriotic phrases. The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with relevant committees. The design for the coins will be based on the original 5-cent coin by James Earle Fraser, featuring a Native American profile and a buffalo. The design will be chosen by the Secretary after consultation with relevant committees. The design will be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility. Minting authority terminates after December 31, 2000. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, a surcharge of $1.00 per coin, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount on sale prices. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to National Museum of the American Indian for commemorating its anniversary and funding endowment and outreach. The Comptroller General can audit the Museum's expenditures. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government for minting coins and require full payment, security, or guarantee for issued coins.
